messages: ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:32): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e or edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e2: re http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Jul/0872.html and "if we add APIs to <canvas> that make it do the same as SVG"

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:32): it seems that some canvas UI developers don't regard being able to manipulate an accessibility API directly as anything like the same as having to build a DOM
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:33): The guys behind Cappuchino took a close look at ARIA, and largely rejected it on the basis that it requires DOM manipulation.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:33): right
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:34): If there's a role for bolt-ons of this sort, it's likely to back widget systems like Cappuchino.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:34): turning <canvas> into a DOM-based model would not make them happy
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:34): I thought Rich was talking about an accessibility API model rather than a DOM model.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:34): which seems to match what the Cappuchino guys were asking for
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:35): http://rossboucher.com/2009/03/01/limitations-of-the-wai-aria/
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:35): is the post I'm thinking of.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:35): thanks
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:35): Rich was talking about an object model as well as an accessibility API as far as I can tell
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:35): okay
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:36): but yeah, maybe we do need an API
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:36): I'm not sure of the practical differences between a DOM and accessibility API manipulation (I've not done any desktop GUI programming).
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:36): I just don't think we should rush into it
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:36): I don't want another ARIA
